pros: This was a great place to work pre-Covid, with Covid it has gotten even better. The company puts their people and their customers at the forefront of everything they do. cons:
Too many layers of leadership are starting to emerge in Technology. There is a push to move to scaled agile frameworks which isn't in the best interests of all areas.

Mangers and senior leadership need more agile coaching. Too many managers still hang on to a command and control style of managing agile teams. Many of the managers themselves are the issue with teams not becoming more self-managing.

review_title: WARNING: Your experience here will depend on your manager
pros:
• Opportunities for working remotely 
• Flexible(ish) hours
• Tons of bonus opportunities
• Uncapped commission
cons:
• God awful micromanagement
• Employees are *encouraged* (borderline required) to have little or no work life balance
• Very difficult to advance in the company
• Contradictory expectations of employees
Advice to Management
Please stop passively criticizing employees for using the PTO they’ve earned. Try using some positive reinforcement every once in a while. Attempt getting to know and understand each employee's strengths; highlight them, encourage them, and lift your employees. AVOID managing by intimidation/ aggression, and for the love of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, stop all the condescending “coaching” of sales reps. 
News flash; It’s SERIOUSLY demotivating.
Helpful
Liberty Mutual Insurance Response
February 5, 2021 – Talent & Enterprise Services
Thanks for sharing your feedback. We do our best to foster an open work environment where employees feel empowered, and we’re always looking for better work-life-balance solutions for our employees. This is an on-going evolution and we rely on feedback like yours to ensure our policies reflect the reality for our employees

I have been working at Liberty Mutual Insurance full-time for more than 5 years

You get paid on time... I struggle to find many pros for working at Liberty Mutual

review_title: The only thing going for this place is Diversity and Inclusion
pros:
Diversity and Inclusion. If you are a new attorney, this place would be good to gain a lot of deposition and arbitration, and bench trial experience, and to learn how to manage your caseload.

The benefits are good.
cons:
No work-life balance. They give you all of this paid time off but only expect you to use 2 weeks of it and bill at 1950, which kind of defeats the purpose of providing such generous time off. 

No mentoring, really. You are basically teaching yourself: extremely high caseload and cookie-cutter law. Claims have the say-so on the cases, including getting experts. Your caseload is so high that you do not have time to strategize your cases unless you work literally every weekend. 

Low pay, extremely unrealistic expectations, a lot of micromanagement. Excessive meetings that Attorneys do not have time for. Everything is to set you up for failure.

Basically, when you add it all up for the amount of work you are doing, it comes out to you practically making minimum wage.
Advice to Management
Listen to your people. Especially, the Attorneys. You have a high turn-over for no reason
Helpfu

Listen to your people. Especially, the Attorneys. You have a high turn-over for no reason

review_title: The Good, The Bad, The Ugly
pros:
-Great benefits
-Team-oriented environment
-Very competitive pay: salary is not great, but there is uncapped commission and it is possible to make $100k-$200k per year
-Tuition Reimbursement 
-Career Advancement
cons:
-Extremely stressful
-Very aggressive sales goals
-Inbound call center environment
-Overtime is not required, but it feels like it is. Sometimes, the scheduling team will update your schedule with lunch overtime without your consent (you can request your full lunch time)
-Commission checks differ vastly from month-to-month making it harder to budget (unless you work 1-2 hours of overtime per day)
-The career advancement is kind of a joke. There are two ways to "prove" yourself at the company: you either work 1-2 hours of overtime per day to become a top seller, or you get in with the right people in leadership.
-Most of the sales supervisors and managers, to your face, will act like they want you to advance in your career, but behind close doors will do nothing to help advance your career
Advice to Management
Stop making career advancement a popularity contest/sales contest. There are a lot of people who would make great leaders/coaches, but never get a chance because management doesn't like them, or because they're unable to "wow" you with their net sales numbers.
Helpful (1)
Liberty Mutual Insurance Response
January 15, 2021 – Talent & Enterprise Services
Thank you for taking the time to share your experience. We're sorry to hear that you’re feeling overextended. We’re always looking for better work-life-balance solutions for our employees. Over the past couple of years, we’ve made significant changes to the way we work, the space we work in, the technology we use and even our dress code to encourage greater flexibility in the workplace. This is an on-going evolution and we rely on feedback like yours to ensure our policies reflect the reality for our employees
advice_to_mgmt: Stop making career advancement a popularity contest/sales contest. There are a lot of people who would make great leaders/coaches, but never get a chance because management doesn't like them, or because they're unable to "wow" you with their net sales numbers.

cons:

-Don't be afraid to discipline or even cut-loose low-producing employees who are not on board with our company mission.

pros: Pay but you will be dead inside
cons:
Everything! You will literally get fired for any little thing at this job. Most were working so many hours of OT without claiming a single hour just to keep up with the workload in fear of being fired for not keeping up or for using OT. If you weren't fired bc of production then you were fired for surveys. If you receive a bad survey then you were on your way out even if the survey was not about you. Don't waste your time or sanity! I saw many ppl go from happy to depressed in less than a year.

No room for promotion. Most just jump to other claims departments when they are about to get fired.

No work/life balance!! NO WORK/LIFE BALANCE! You do not have the opportunity to work down much of your claims before a vacation so you have extremely angry customers when you return. Co-workers will try to help while you are out but they are swamped with their own work.
Advice to Management
You will never be a top company if you do not look after your employees. Management should be held accountable for the high turnover rate.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: You will never be a top company if you do not look after your employees. Management should be held accountable for the high turnover rate.

review_title: Bled blue and drank the Kool-Aid for many years
pros: Industry-leading compensation, golden handcuffs of sorts.
cons:
Constant reorgs, realignments, rationalizations. Totally understand that if you're not changing, your dying but LM has taken this to a whole new level. No sense of job security, even for top performers in Sr. Leadership. Find a balance between pushing on
Advice to Management
Stop saying you're a technology company that happens to sell insurance until you're ready to start behaving like it. Commitment to D&I is admirable but the pendulum is swinging fast and it got downright weird. Too much of a good thing can become toxic. Promote the best and most qualified candidates and role model what a diverse organization looks like at the top. A bunch of white dudes telling everyone that the org needs more diversity in senior leadership is a head scratcher.
Helpful (2

I was told to hold off on a project via email then told in a performance review I was receiving a bad review because I never tried to do the project on my own with no other input other than "use tool x to do stuff".
Agile isn't actually used just a bastardized form of it that they can use to hold developers to whatever sprint deadline they want (they change mid sprint, often, as does your workload.) I also once witnessed one of my co workers be unable to describe what the absolute value function did (removes negative sign) when discussing an SQL query. 

 The majority of the "innovation" is window dressing done by managerial staff that's been there for 10+ years and sees change as a way to loose their 6 figure salary, which is all they probably have cared about for the past decade anyway. If you suck up to them and make them feel good about their bad decisions and poor management they will promote you quickly. If you do anything else you get given grunt work and inevitably fired for "poor performance" which they will refuse to describe.

If you do want to stay there, never talk to people outside your team or your manager will not only know they will reprimand you. You must ask all things of your manager and hope that they somehow go and talk to the people you could just email directly. Why? Because. Shut up and take it or leave.

This isn't a development environment its a 19th century work house where the managers are the staff and their underlings are children, who should be seen but not heard.

I could go on. You were warned!
Advice to Management
None. Cant fix stupid.
Helpfu

None. Cant fix stupid.

review_title: Liberty has lost it's luster, and is more of a sinking ship now
pros: Good Benefits, Nice Office, Loved the projects and actual work, good partnership between Product and UX
cons:
- Awful Office Politics: you only get recognized if you're going out and drinking with the team after work - forget advancement if you have a family life. Hard work does not pay off here, in fact it doesn't even matter. Manager was checked out any time we had a one on one meeting, often late and then distracted. Management is swapped out pretty regularly so you have to 'start over' every year almost.
- Terrible Work/Life Balance (Pre-Covid): They expect you in the office every day and if you choose to work from home they don't accommodate you in meetings and leave you out of important communication when its very easy to jump on Slack or a meeting. - Inequality in the workplace: was held back during my pregnancy and taken off projects because my manager didn't want to put too much on my plate, however I was very capable and extremely put off by this. I didn't feel comfortable going to senior management with this since I've had bad experiences in the past with concerns that went unanswered or ignored.
Advice to Management
Really take a look at what's happening here: the hard working talent has either left the company or is out the door because they aren't recognized for their efforts. End of year reviews come as a surprise when all throughout the year things are looking good, and then you're hit with a surprise. Communication is everything. Drop the office politics. Invest in talent and hold your managers accountable. Ever since the "Digital Transformation" things have been going downhill. Stop prioritizing IT group over everyone else.
Helpful (6)
Liberty Mutual Insurance Response
December 11, 2020 – Talent & Enterprise Services
Thank you for taking the time to write a review and provide your honest feedback. We’ve made significant changes to the way we work, the space we work in, and the technology we use to encourage greater flexibility in the workplace, and we are committed to ongoing improvement in this area. And we take allegations of discrimination or harassment seriously - if you feel you have witnessed discrimination, please do not hesitate to report your concerns to Employee Relations

pros: Clear objectives, plenty of resources to help you do your job, mostly friendly co-workers, and mostly supportive management team. As with most things, the more experienced/knowledgeable the manager or co-worker is, the more helpful they are. However, in recent years, management has been more open/honest with goals, expectations, and company-wide changes. They have 1-2 flexible work from home days per week, which is great for employees with children. The amount of paid time off per year is great.
cons:
You're expected to handle a large amount of claim files (150-2000. You'll definitely run into situations where you think a file should be handled in a one way, but management disagrees, leading to uncomfortable conversations with claimants or their representatives. If you want to get a promotion, you'll definitely have to work on projects that are outside of daily claims work. While the company's official position is that they do no/ like/want their employees to work outside of typical business hours or work more than 40hrs/wk (there is no overtime pay), most tenured employees that meet their claims/project goals will confirm that they work at least a little more than 40hrs/wk.

review_title: Beware - Not what it once was
pros: Great compensation and bonus program. Benefits used to be good, but keep getting worse and more expensive for the employee every year.
cons:
This is a large company and you can move around and find career advancement, but there's a lot of bad management, full of inept and self-promoting egotistical managers . The bonus structure is great as long as it's not a bad year for natural disasters to hurt revenue, but it also means managers will push their teams past exhaustion in order to achieve their goals and obtain their huge bonuses, creating morale issues. And layoffs . . . like many large companies, you are expendable. I knew many people who had been there 15-20 years, get let go with no warning. 

From an IT perspective, they try to present themselves as if they're cutting edge and creating a culture like Google or some large tech company, when in reality they have so much tech debt they're kidding themselves and don't have the the financial or personnel resources to be what they present in their public relations or what James McGlennon promotes in his Forbes interview. True tech talent doesn't come to a big insurance company normally, so it's thin. To make matters worse, they offshore almost all of their operational support to India to save money, but it consistently proves to be a terrible model and only creates immense frustration and inefficiency. 

Lastly, they like to promote themselves as being "diverse" and empowering women in IT. This is true . . . my last manager was a woman put in place that had zero IT infrastructure experience, so I got the joy of explaining elementary principles of systems administration while her eyes glazed over and knew I'd have to explain it again at some point in the future. They want more woman in IT, which is great if they're qualified, but they're short-sited on the fact the field is predominantly men. It should be gender neutral and simply promote the most qualified candidate rather than place unqualified personnel into positions just to claim you're "diverse."
Advice to Management
Do right by your employees and stop the PR propaganda
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Do right by your employees and stop the PR propaganda

review_title: High Paying Company that makes you earn it
pros:
-A company concerned with employees well-being, diversity + inclusion, and doing the 'right thing' for it's customers
-A company that encourages internal employee movement across teams, depts, and areas of expertise
cons:
-Tone at the top puts a lot of pressure on those below; i.e. if it's a priority for the business, HR has to make it happen, regardless of the cost to its employees and their capacity
-Liberty pays it's employees very well, but that comes at a cost. Work is poured onto those that have proven themselves as performers, and "work/life balance" becomes more of a token phrase to hire new talent and less of a practice that is encouraged and followed day to day given how busy all departments are.
Advice to Management
Running lean is good for the bottom line, but at the cost of those doing the work. Hiring may not be an option in the time of a pandemic, but being realistic about what can be accomplished is. Take time to reflect on those bearing the brunt of the work.

I got my sanity back after leaving this position. You will get drained and frustrated a lot while working from home full time in this position. Job takes at least a year to get good at; but employees are getting fired in under a year. Pretty unfair. Would not recommend to those who have families or children at home to tend to; especially while COVID-19 protocols are still in place. There’s a reason they are in a hiring surge... Good employees being let go, not enough help/support right now, extremely high claim volumes.
Advice to Management
Half of the office knew an employee was getting fired before the actual employee did. Very unprofessional and disappointing. Also shows that there was likely no way to fight for the job even if the employee wanted to. Once you’re on the “radar” there’s no coming back; even if you’ve been in the role less than a year.

review_title: Don't Trust Any Level of Management or Anything the Company Says
pros: Loved working with my Teammates
cons:
Only metrics count, targets are always moving up, so you can never meet them. Extremely high workload, totally unmanageable. Gives lip service to work-life balance, but you go home so exhausted you can't have a life. Pay does not meet costs of living, and any increases are within tightly controlled ranges. Bonuses are also within tightly controlled ranges, and do not accurately reflect actual personal contribution. CEO pay and benefits are outrageously high compared with frontline workers. Office "parties" and company supplied lunches are a sop to diminishing worker enthusiasm. Extreme favoritism. Primary method of management is gaslighting and a target on your back. Layoffs, outsourcing, and constant reorganization are the norm, as the company needs more money for expansion. So there is no job security. But it never reduces top management pay or benefits.
Advice to Management
The annual Employee Opinion Survey could be extremely beneficial, if you actually paid attention to employee comments. The decision to be in the top 3 insurance providers worldwide was the worst management decision ever! You went from being the best and well-respected and a great place to work to being nehhh!

Helpfu

review_title: Good Company but like every other corporate beast
pros: Benefits are not too expensive, work from home is almost permanent, flexible management as far as time off and empathizing, vacation accrues at a steady rate- low but steady, and company is financially stable which means job stability.
cons:
Front line employees are used and abused just like most corporate entities. In APD Department if you’re looking to go into Management— good luck. It’s more about who you know and when they’re ready for you to go than anything else. Pay is lacking compared to the amount of hand holding you’ll do for the customer and the stress you’ll have to endure daily with the unmanageable workload isn’t worth it. For most adjusters it’s just a ticking clock till they get fired because their work quality will be terrible because they’re burnt out. metrics will steadily increase and drive you nuts because you’re working your butt off to stay afloat and here comes the new metric to push more work outta you.
Advice to Management
Thank you for the opportunity. I have personal issues to deal with regarding medical. However, claims should definitely pay adjusters a lot more and not give any one adjuster such a strenuous workload considering they will only make about $45k year after taxes if they’re lucky. Not really worth the duress and stressful days. Also, when I started at Liberty I negotiated for more money but kept getting my salary flattened twice—first at the beginning when I came to APD I didn’t get a raise at all and secondly at promotion time in APD I was not provided an adequate raise($1500 yearly salary increase or so)which made me a lot closer to the APD average pay quartile- meaning my pay raise was based solely on what everyone else was making in APD as well as my initial on-boarding salary in RMD instead of my current metrics and work ethic. Not fair in my opinion that I receive less raises over time because I negotiated upfront but I’m still held to the same work expectations as others after promotion. Basically what that’s saying to me is due to your initial salary being higher you will continually get less at raise time, subsequently less bonus and overall compensation overtime than everyone else. Yet you still will have to do the same additional responsibilities as everyone else that come with promotion. Also, everyone else will be getting closer to what you are making because your raises and subsequent bonus will be flattened out to be closer to theirs. My initial salary was based on my experience and negotiating ability so why do I have to be averaged out when I switch departments and/or during promotion within that department. Please change that culture and take care of your people financially so that they can deal with medical problems, etc and be able to purchase things in their life. I was also passed for total loss twice when that’s what I interviewed for and switched to entry level express claims when my bodily injury, total loss, theft/fire, and dealers blanket experience should have yielded me more earning potential. I tried to make it work but when you have anxiety and other medical problems being slighted on top of receiving a very heavy workload on day to day basis only intensifies your anxiety and medical issues because you are not receiving proper compensation for your sacrifice. You are being penalized for your experience, you are being penalized for going to express claims, you are penalized in overall compensation all because you had prior insurance experience and negotiated when you joined. Again thank you for the opportunity and understanding! Retention is key and key to retention is attrition and employee morale. Do right by them financially in claims and provide manageable workload so that they can enjoy life and do right by you. I enjoyed the job when I felt that I had equivalent responsibilities compared to my pay but my anxiety and physical pain only grew as my responsibilities grew but my earning potential continued to get flattened at every review.
Helpful (4

review_title: Good company, but it's lost its luster
pros: Competitive Salary, Great Benefits, Flexible Work Arrangements
cons:
Sr. Management has had same communicated vision to be top 3 carrier for 10 years with no real progress toward goal. 

There is are frequent reductions-in-force that frequently are the result not of changing market conditions as senior leadership wants to indicate, but poor planning. As example, the company completely eliminated business analyst positions with their shift to Agile, but did not address in the new agile model who should do that work. This resulted in severe gaps that forced remaining employees to do more work with less resources. 

The company despite having record profits year over year continues to squeeze expenses using incomprehensible methods. As example, people traveling for work were told they couldn't order breakfast on company dime, while the company would spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to give everyone in the company a small branded item or mailer. Not to mention the well published story that the company spent millions of dollars renovating the CEO's office when he assumed his role in 2012. 

While salary and benefits are competitive, your success really depends on who your manager is at the company. Some leaders are great and will work hard to recognize talent. Other groups though are decidedly less invested in promoting talent which is discouraging. 

There are frequent changes in reporting structure due to the constant realignments/reorgs which makes it challenging to not only get work done, but to also advance one's career.
Advice to Management
Solidify on one vision and create actionable steps to achieve it. Quit being reactionary and trying to cover for poor leadership vision/execution by expense reduction. The expense reduction might help your bottom line look better, but it masks the real cause of issues with the company while harming the very people who are helping you succeed. 

Quit rewarding senior leadership's expense reduction efforts. It is harmful to employees. 

I raised these issues through assigned project work and was essentially blackballed by my leadership team. It's why I voluntarily left the company. Liberty used to be a great company - but the culture has unfortunately become toxic.

review_title: Liberty takes the "fun" out of dysfunction
pros: It might be better than being unemployed.
cons:
Trying to do your job at Liberty Mutual is like swimming through wet cement. The managers who don't/can't lead, the complete lack of communication, and the dysfunctional bureaucracy combine to kill any sense of accomplishment or fulfillment for employees. Liberty is a 100-year old bureaucratic monstrosity that will never change, no matter how many people quit. (And quitting was the best thing I ever did.)
Advice to Management
Stop drinking your own Koolaid. Middle management knows you only want to hear that everything's great, so that's what they tell you--and they punish any rank-and-file employee that tries to speak up. All your Net Promoter Scores and the other metrics you're so obsessed with are meaningless, because employees are telling you what you want to hear.

June 25, 2020 – Talent and Enterprise Services
I appreciate you taking the time to share your feedback. I’m sorry to hear about your experience in Chandler. We are committed to creating an inclusive work environment, where all employees can bring their full selves to work and thrive, and it concerns me that you had a different experience. While we have put key programs and initiatives in place to build our foundation in important areas such as unconscious bias awareness and inclusion capabilities, like many Fortune 500 companies, we know we have more work to do and we are committed to doing that work. Liberty Mutual continues to advance our D&I learning opportunities and tools for employees to help us disrupt bias, such as the Race & Ethnicity Collaboration Workshops for managers and Speaker Series for all employees, and Inclusion In Action, a mini-series designed to help all employees further develop their inclusion skills and capabilities. We take these matters very seriously and encourage you to reach out the Liberty Mutual HR Support Center so we can address the issues you raise. 

-Dawn Frazier-Bohnert
SVP, Global Diversity & Inclusion Office

Helpfu

pros: Pay is slightly above standard as far as insurance sales go.
cons:
Commission structure changes constantly. It literally changed as I went through training and 4 more times in my two years here. 

My specific department is ACT don't get suckered into that you'll do far better in normal inbound. Leads that are purchased for my queue don't want insurance. 

I've had 3 managers in the past 4 months.

Goals went from 35 a month to 80 on the latest commission structure. if you're applying for a normal "inbound" position then the goals are over 110 right now. 

Work Environment isn't the worst however you basically have to "log" when you go to the restroom. Meaning you're either at your desk the entire day or you will hear from management. 

They use to be flexible with scheduling but not any more. 

I'm normally not one to complain about my employer but this is typically how a commission job works it's "amazing" when you get there but over time the higher ups want more in their pockets so structure changes form rep making a lot of money to rep doing more work to make less.
Advice to Management
Turn over is so high through management that I don't think it would matter if you listened. You really need to remember that this company employs the best people to sell a product that people don't think they need so treat your employees better. Only reason most of us still work here is because of Covid-19 otherwise I'd reply to the four other offers from other companies on my LinkedIn.

pros: They have a great 401k, vacation and pension and also best thing is one day paid per year to volunteer at the charity of your choice and once a year you can donate to the charity of your choice and they will match your donation.

Too much work and too much stress to get the work done and did not want to hire more people to help with the overload, also the computer systems were down quite often which added to getting behind in your work load and the upper management did not take that into account, when they would tell you that you were behind on your work load. The expectations were too high towards the end of my employment, which led to severe health issues and I left.

Purchase a higher speed internet connection and listen to your employees when they tell you they are overloaded, even though I also know most of the managers were also put to expectations that were too high. Also, if your secretaries want to work from home - let them, especially since quite a few of the secretaries work in remote offices.

pros: SOME team members. Half of the members of my team were smart, innovative, helpful.

Dishonesty from managers; 50% of your colleagues will be back-stabbing gossipers (and those are the 50% who don't do the work but butt-kiss and play the political game. The reason they feel compelled to gossip is because they are insecure and are fearful of the tech-savvy members of the team. Make no mistake: this company is FULL of polities. MUCH more so than any other company for which I have worked.) 

Why do you think there are occasional "hiring surges?" They will tell you it's because they are growing so fast. Don't believe the BULL. Then there are the constant reorgs. There's a reason this company doesn't even rank in the list to "Best Insurance Companies to Work For." And don't even get me started on the whole "locker room" situation. (No one has an assigned desk, so you have to put your stuff into a locker. What a crock!)

review_title: Ok for new professionals, but not long term - get out before you become jaded.
pros: Decent 401k. Many positions have flexible work arrangements. They used to be a good, positive company and may be able to get there again.
cons:
Employees are not trusted and treated like commodities. Negative culture. Political atmosphere. Favorites stay and do nothing with no consequences. Top performers are overworked to make up for it. Raises are unfair and the basis for them are difficult to make sense of. Promotions are almost non-existent, even for top performers. They only promote yes-men who are zombies to the Liberty culture. Benefits dropping constantly. Downsizing and laying off randomly. No real positive direction for this company.
Advice to Management
Realize that your employees are your greatest asset and treat them like such. STOP WITH THE CONSTANT TURNOVER. Realize where you have problems and take real steps to fix them. Be transparent and learn to take criticisms. Your upper level managers hide from anything negative - to the extent employees are warned to keep their mouths shut unless they have positive things to say.

The days of paralegal teams being supported and encouraged their respective coordinators are long gone, with the days now filled by the complete and utter lack of any legitimate respect towards the paralegals by the clueless dictators (aka paralegal coordinators), turning the entire office into a custerfudge of resentment, embarrassment, shame, and paranoia. Helpfu

pros: Nice building, free coffee, Spacious desks.
cons:
If you're looking for work-life balance, SPRINT for the hills. There is absolutely NO work life balance in this position. Sure, they pay better than the rest of the insurance companies for similar positions but best believe they will work you to death. Not worth it. Worst of it.... they don't let you do overtime! Wait so you want outstanding metrics, great customer survey scores, all claims handled in a timely manner.... but don't want us to do overtime? CHEAP company. There are plenty of insurance companies out there with no cap on overtime. Sounds like you want a filet mignon for sirloin price. Cheapest company I have worked for. They will lie to you and say that there is "unlimited" overtime, yet if you work even a few hours of overtime you will get a mandatory meeting with your manager. And no, it's not a "thank you for working hard" meeting. Look I am not going to lie to you... the building is brand new, the amenities in the building are great, free coffee, blah, blah. None of it is worth the stress and turmoil they put you through. I have seen people leave this position within a few weeks of working. Training is complete trash. They don't provide substantial training and resources adequate enough for even experienced adjusters to do their job. Just pretend that there is no training. This position bases your 90% of your performance, bonus, and promotion opportunity on one thing - THE CUSTOMER SURVEY. Best believe some customers don't even know how to fill out the survey and as a result, you might get a bad survey score even though you bended over backwards to help the customer and the customer was satisfied. Oh, and it actually happens a lot. And there is NO WAY for you or your manager to "toss out" that survey. I've seen some of the best adjusters leave the company because of the fact that there is no work-life balance. Sure, they don't time your breaks and lunches like some other companies do but you will soon WISH they did because you're SINKING in your claim load and realize that you need to skip your breaks and lunches. Why the need to skip breaks and lunches, you ask? Oh wait!! BECAUSE THEY DON'T ALLOW OVERTIME. The best way to explain what it feels like to work here is to imagine someone throwing you in deep water, and you don't know how to swim... oh, and there is an anchor tied to your feet. There is so so much I want to say about this company and my experience here I could write for days. Don't get me wrong, there are some people who do well in this position. You know why? They bend their back for the customers and say whatever they want to appease them. Not happy with liability? I will change it. Not happy with the appraiser? Let me get you another one. If you're fine with waiting HAND AND FOOT to appease customers and lying to them and giving up your integrity and dignity in your life, then for sure ... I DARE YOU TO TRY THIS JOB. No I am not a "bitter" ex-employee who got fired and thus, wrote this post for revenge. I am writing to warn you because I wish I would have read a post like this myself, or have had someone to tell me about this position, and understood what this position really was like BEFORE I got hired into this position. If you're looking for a message or a sign, let this be it.
Advice to Management
See above. You have a lot to fix. Just because you want to be one of the "top" insurance companies doesn't mean overworking your employees is a good idea. Claims volume is a complete joke. I challenge you to find an adjuster who doesn't agree with what I wrote above. Many are on the verge of quitting, you just don't know and why would we tell you beforehand. Update your resources. Abysmal how your resource pages have broken links. Many adjusters take anti-depressants and anti-anxiety meds because of this job. Many of y'all are quick to point out what we're doing "wrong" yet when y'all go on lunch, we can't help but talk about whether or not y'all can even handle our workload. No cap

review_title: Not the way it needs to be
pros: Good pay and adequate benefits; takes interest in surrounding communities and had a great diversity/inclusion agenda for a Fortune 100 company; annual salary raises and performance bonuses.
cons:
Inadequate work ratios. Company tries to put forward a work-life balance appearance but it’s forced. No OT unless things are very far behind schedule. Tasks are consistently taken away that would be considered standard work in any other office setting - making meeting annual goals of billable hours harder. Hours of operation are flexible, however no one is allowed to work outside of those hours, even though it’s the request of an employee. Limited availability to occasionally work from home unless you hold a specific title. 

Annual raise is based on a sliding scale system that is dependent on reviews by management and/or other assigned supervisors. Because of a salary cap, raises are usually less than any kind of cost of living increase. The company has strongly adopted the “do more with less” adage - making it a stressful environment. Some positions have no upward mobility unless you want to become management.

pros:
Company- 
I fell I love with this company years ago (when I was in a different position) because of their values and work life balance. They have a yearly volunteer day to allow employees to give back to their communities and support employee chosen charities with donations. Most offices have flex space options giving you a 2-3 day work from home schedule. 

Adjuster role:
Work from home, salary pay, company vehicle w/ pleasure use, gas card, cellphone, all the office equipment you need, make you own schedule.
cons:
No work life Balance. Job is supposed to be a 9-10 hr job but it's more like 12 hr when your first starting out. Exceeding Metrics- forget about it for a few years. Goals are not attainable unless through cutting corners and working yourself sick. The expectations they give customers are not realistic so your constantly apologizing and trying to buy time. Turnover rate is ridiculous and I know they have increased pay and changed a few things over the years to try to combat that but they are not there yet.
Advice to Management
Be honest about the way the workload affects people and become a pioneer in the claims industry to change that. Higher more reps and reduce the claim intake to 6-8 per week vs 10. This would greatly reduce the turnover rate, which gives you the ability to cultivate a knowledgeable workforce that takes pride in their role. 

Provide a different training program for new adjusters coming in with no claim experience. 

Liberty Mutual is a great company but they are failing in this department.

review_title: It was only a matter of time - Claims Adjuster
pros: The only real perks aside then getting the Fortune 50 company on your resume, would be work from home, the 401k matching and the training. Some of the people are decent when you actually get the chance to see them; but you rarely even associate with anyone even on on your own team let alone others.
cons:
Company needs to focus more on their employees, proper hiring and the workload. It’s a huge company so take that as it is, you’re basically a number and metric. The workload has become absolutely unbearable since Liberty adjusters started handling Safeco customer claims and vice verse. Of course they say it’s supposed to level the workload but try quadrupling it. Oh, and ya absolutely no overtime, so good luck. 

The ONE team approach each team manager boasts is a crock and pray they like you. If not, that favoritism card will be pulled faster than you can imagine and the team manager controls workloads (even though they claim it’s level). 

There is a reason more people are quitting faster they can hire. Also, don’t voice a concern or you paint a huge target on your back and good luck with trying to promote (That’s also you’re team managers choice). Been with 4 TMs within 4 years and only 2 were solid and yet no longer with the company....hmm
Advice to Management
Value your team members as they will leave you or give you terrible surveys which we all know, is even worse. Team managers and this company live and die for surveys so keep that in member fellow pawns. Maybe hire more talent so customers can get proper service. Also, so the employees aren’t pulling their hair out with immeasurable amounts of work.

review_title: Five plus years experience - overall good but large company mentality gets exhausting
pros:
- Emphasis on Diversity & Inclusion (including diversifying leadership)
- HR seems to be making progress on some great initiatives for employees, including recently improved Maternity leave policy.
- From a competitive standpoint, the companies resources and scale help in the marketplace
- Worked with some great people within my Business Unit but had little involvement with other business units
cons:
- Political environment and a feeling like you have to pay your dues to climb the ladder, which is discouraging to younger, ambitious talent
- Things are constantly changing, whether it be corporate structure, technology, benefits, etc. This is typical of a large company so not necessarily a fault of Liberty's but rather the nature of a corporation this large.
Advice to Management
Kudos to management for the investment in D&I, and I hope within a few years here is more diversity reflected in management and leadership rather than just at the individual contributor level. Do more to listen to and obtain feedback from middle level employees that are 'in the trenches' day to day before you make changes or shift strategy; decisions often feel very top down and illogical to 'middle level' employees that are often most impacted by changes.

review_title: The Investment Department - Fixed Income Research
pros: Allows you to travel to conferences, support CFA exams and allows work from home twice a month
cons:
1. Over staffed and lack upward mobility. Only junior guys have real industry coverage and real work to do. Even that, each person’s coverage is relatively light. Managers barely have much coverage. Yet there are layers of managements just in research.

2. Lack of accountability and lack of investment acumen in management. The management are more concerned about managing up and can care less about managing down. There is minimal interest in investments and markets. Investment style is to avoid all headline risk and is extremely risk averse. When things go wrong, they blame the junior research analysts. 

3. When things go wrong, it is always the junior guys fault. Never the portfolio management team’s fault. Yet they only serve one portfolio management team who makes up their own mind but don’t take any responsibilities. 

4. The investment department changes employee compensation twice in 18 months, cut people’s pay and made promotion a lot harder.
Helpful (1

pros: Reasonable pay and work life balance (they don’t want to have to pay you for overtime)
cons:
Very conservative and behind the times in regards to both workplace culture and in their tech stacks. 
I was told women should wear makeup in skype meetings and for in trouble for asking if their were free mensuration products in the building. 
There is so much tech debt 90% of anything people are working on is outdated software from 2015 or earlier. The code I’ve worked on was so embarrassing to see made it into production-riddled with bugs and typos.

Also, the company is very stingy. I felt my salary and that of my colleagues was pretty good, but beyond that their benefits aren’t great and they’ll almost never give half days and you have to use your vacation days when you get sick (some teams aren’t allowed to work from home?).

I’ve also seen a lot of mismanagement and micromanaging. It’s frustrating being under the thumb of people who are just plain bad at their jobs but since they’ve been at the company so long no one does anything
Advice to Management
Seriously re-think how you want to recruit new people in tech and how you treat your new tech employees. It’s relatively easy to find another job and people who care about their work will leave/are leaving and all you’re left with are the people who are either lazy about their careers or don’t have the skills for the job.

review_title: Good company to work for, but.....
pros: Offering 3 day WFH in 2020; Finally gave us MLK day as a paid holiday; Tuition Reimbursement;
cons:
No real advancement opportunities for supervisors. Senior leadership complains about expenses, but is constantly sponsoring "summits" and gatherings where all people do is drink and charge it to their corporate card. Sending Underwriting Assistant jobs offshore and calling it "Role Evolution". No loyalty to long time employees. There are too many project teams taking up valuable time meeting about changing workflow processes that don't need to be changed instead of focusing on figuring out why our system crashes after every system release. Lack of diversity in front line underwriting, and of course no one is checking.
Advice to Management
While I understand you are running a business and need to make money, instead of laying off hardworking Underwriting Assistants that have been loyal to you for years, why don't you shave off some of the layers of management that aren't doing anything to bring in revenue. If you're going to promote Diversity & Inclusion, make sure all your managers and senior leaders are on the same page. Liberty Mutual is still practicing the "good ol boys" mentality and are discriminating against people who are applying for internal positions left and right. Start making your managers accountable for their actions when they don't follow your guidelines for inclusion because too many people are being EXCLUDED. Stop hiring college hires for UW Trainee positions that do nothing but stay long enough to pay off their college loans, rack up expenses traveling for training, then leave to work for a competitor when you could have hired an internal person who really wants an insurance career and have been loyal to the company for years.

review_title: This company is going downhill day after day
pros: The Pay and the Time Off
cons:
Literally everything else I can think of. When I started years ago, I thought this company was one of the best companies ever. I actually was happy for a time being. But then slowly but surely things changed. Like many other businesses, all this company cares about is the money. I constantly hear complaints from our clients about how low we are ranked and a quick google search will show that's true. Consumer reports as of 2019 has ranked us at the bottom, even though we charge some of the highest prices. Almost all insurance rankings currently has us at the bottom. Hmmmm I wonder why? It's extremely hard when someone cancels there policy and they have more and better coverages with a higher ranked company than us. What are we really supposed to say in that situation? The truth is there is nothing we can legitimately say that would make logical sense to the customer besides a bunch of nonsense that that wont care about.
Advice to Management
This is directly for the Tampa location. If your going to play favoritism, at least be upfront about it. It's truly sad how deep the level of favoritism goes within this office, and being that gossip is so heavy why even hide it anymore. I've been told by multiple people they've received promotions because they "knew the right people" or they worked there way up by the "brownie points system" and other things that I wouldn't feel comfortable saying on here. It's sad that you already know who's going to get a job before it even posts online, haha. You all are going to self destruct within....

review_title: Dishonest, unethical company. Avoid at all costs!
pros:
- Met some good people
- There's tuition reimbursement
- Nice Severance package
- You learn a lot about insurance.
cons:
At Liberty Mutual, job security does not exist. There are constant, constant layoffs at this company. The number of layoffs is accelerating because Liberty Mutual is moving many job functions to India, and they are also in the process of transitioning licensed insurance jobs (such as licensed Customer Service Agents) to contractors that make $9 per hour with no benefits. Management, of course, will deny this, but the writing is on the wall. Management has given the contractors and India representatives more and more work. If you enjoy working under the constant threat of layoff, you will love working here. The CEO even said in a town hall earlier in 2019 that there would be no more layoffs this year, and of course, that was a big lie. Are you a Liberty Mutual policyholder? Need help with your policy? Congratulations, if you email Liberty, an unlicensed worker in India is changing your policy or providing you coverage advice. (I question the legality of this. Coverage advice and policy changes are supposed to be done by licensed U.S. agents) Liberty Mutual does not want their policyholders to know that India is doing the work now, and this speaks to the total lack of transparency at the company.
Also, the front line representatives (claims reps, service reps, sales agents) do some of the hardest work in the company at low pay. Meanwhile, there are thousands of employees who make $70k+ per year to maybe work 2-3 hours total per day and spend most of their day binge-watching Netflix. (Must be nice!!) Meanwhile, the front line is stressing from extreme micromanagement while getting paid peanuts. How about actually paying for the amount of work done?
Senior Management is awful. They are dishonest and incompetent. Senior Management has instructed middle management & supervisors to “coach out” employees who give out low Employee Opinion Survey scores. Liberty claims the surveys are anonymous, AND THAT’S A LIE! I’ve seen several employees pulled into a room to have a ‘discussion’ about their surveys. I’ve seen several responses on other reviews from a Liberty employee encouraging people to reach out to the compliance hotline or have discussions with their manager with their concerns. This is useless because Liberty Mutual retaliates against employees. They claim to have a ‘no retaliation’ policy, but of course, that is another lie. If you voice any concerns, you will be targeted. That’s a fact.
Senior management’s incompetence is the biggest cause of the layoffs. They make horrible decisions which cost the company a ton of money, so they lay off a bunch of people to cut costs. The excuse always is: “We believe this change will better position us for the future.” There is a total lack of accountability with them. It’s frustrating. In addition, Liberty has had to jack up rates to bring in more money to cover up for their incompetence. The result: a product that is very poorly priced compared to the competition. You would be amazed how many policies are cancelled per day because of the awful rates Liberty offers.
Advice to Management
STOP LAYING PEOPLE OFF!!!
Helpful (27
advice_to_mgmt: STOP LAYING PEOPLE OFF!!!

review_title: Make your money and run. This is a job, not a career.
pros:
-Pay can be really good. I'd say the top 10% of sellers here are making six figures. With most experienced reps averaging around $70,000/yr. They definitely pay employees better than any other insurance company and as far as I know this applies for not only sales, but other departments as well. Sadly, the best way to make money in the inside sales job is to ignore everything you don't like about working here, suck it up and pretend everything's great. If you can't do that, you won't make good money.
- Working only 37.5 hours a week is a plus, however you may end up working more than that to hit your goals.
- Received a company trip for performance
- Can be good a job if you're looking to grind for 1-2 years just to make money, but would never recommend for someone out of college looking for a long term career.
cons:
- HR doesn't reveal the full truth about the job before hiring you. Our first day on the job my training group was informed that we would be working a graveyard shift (12:30pm-9:00pm) for the first 3 months after completing training. They also said we would have the option to work Saturdays, but instead we were forced to work 3/4 Saturdays a month. 
-Company DOES NOT care about you in this job, only your numbers. Liberty Mutual claimed it overpaid myself and 3 of my team members one month. So then they took back roughly $2,000 from each of us!!! We basically started the following months with negative commission and had to work our way out of a hole. WHAT KIND OF COMPANY ASKS FOR MONEY BACK FROM ITS EMPLOYEES???
- The company is adamant about expecting data accuracy from sales reps, yet can't accurately count our sales! They can see every single thing you do on your computer, and hear every word you say to a customer. However, when a sales rep might be missing a sale instead of going back and looking at our calls to see that we did sell it, you are out of luck. I can think of a couple different times when I did not get properly paid for sales, one of which resulted in the company taking $2,000 back from me. 
- Job mobility and development is absolutely terrible. Many people get stuck in this call center, because top reps make more money than supervisors and moving into another department means taking a huge pay cut. Rather than develop you for an area you show interest in, you'll just be expected to keep producing sales each month.
-Everything you do here is monitored. There is a lightbulb above your desk that shows if you are taking calls or not. Breaks, and lunches are timed.
- You don't get all the same holidays off as other departments in the company. We received an email from the CEO that July 5th would be a company holiday this year, yet that was not true for the inside sales department.
- While the quantity of leads is usually good, the quality of the leads is despicable. You can expect very high rates compared to competitors, and a good number of your leads are just sent to you via some else's cold calls. You'll get treated like crap by customers and cussed out about once a week. Someone will call in about a quote they did online and then as soon as you touch it, the price jumps by 10% because Liberty gives an online discount, forcing sales reps to lie to customers about how the price has gone up if they want to sell it. A majority of the leads have horrible coverage, they are shmucks just looking to save a few dollars. Then when you quote them a higher price, they say "YOUR AD SAID YOU COULD SAVE ME MONEY! THIS IS FALSE ADVERTISING." And you will sit there listening to them bicker about their "perfect" driving record for 3 more minutes before they finally hang up on you.
Advice to Management
-HR needs to give an honest explanation of the job hours before hiring.
-Develop your talent here. You let gifted, and educated young professionals leave because you never ask what their long term goals are and where they'd like to end up in the company, nor do you make any effort to get them there.
-Keep sales goal at 45 each month so sales reps know what to expect. If people make less money during slower months and a lot of money in the busier months, who cares! The constant goal changing just seems like a way to protect the company from paying too much to employees.
-Don't send people a letter in the mail that says we can save them money, and then tell us to sell to customers based on value. If our marketing says "save money" our sales focus needs to be "saving money". Otherwise it doesn't work.

review_title: Forget ERISA, Just Deny The Claim
pros:
Liberty is a straightforward place to work, if you've worked at one insurance company, you've worked here.

If you just want to come in an pick up a paycheck, without having to return phone calls of claimants, this is a great place to work. Ignoring calls, not returning voicemail, etc are all generally accepted, and your supervisor won't hassle you about it.
cons:
The claims policies are designed to result in a denial regardless of the merits of the claim itself, especially with employer policies that are covered under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, because even an actively fraudulent denial (which happens daily, by design) won't result in any costs to the company unless a US Attorney decides to prosecute..... which they don't. If that's the kind of place you want to work, go for it - it's safe and secure, as long as you don't mind hurting people already injured and unable to work.
Advice to Management
Keep up what you're doing, but also keep an eye on potential prosecutions and regulations. You'll need to make some pretty major changes to operations if claimants get a cause of action for fraudulently denied claims, especially with the clinicians fabricating statements. 

Since I don't think the regulatory environment will change (and ERISA pretty much makes us immune to most fraud claims) we're in good shape in the future, just be ready to drastically change operations if a claim for equity ever gets accepted.
Helpful (8
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep up what you're doing, but also keep an eye on potential prosecutions and regulations. You'll need to make some pretty major changes to operations if claimants get a cause of action for fraudulently denied claims, especially with the clinicians fabricating statements. 

Since I don't think the regulatory environment will change (and ERISA pretty much makes us immune to most fraud claims) we're in good shape in the future, just be ready to drastically change operations if a claim for equity ever gets accepted.

review_title: Losing your soul and individuality to the corporate machine
pros: Easy to get hired, easy to get by, paid well for your happiness.
cons:
LM likes to purport that they care about individual employees and value diversity, but the simple truth is above all else Liberty wants to sell itself as an ideal workplace while not needing to put in the effort. Leadership is constantly changing their direction and constantly unveiling "new and innovative methods," trying to sound like a true technology company, even though what they sell is insurance and pretty words. Working as a developer for over 3 years here, I've learned that despite endless technical instability and outdated business methods, Liberty has no intent to change its approach. Just recently all workers in my area were moved to a different building, and are now subject to a new seat reservation system. As someone that comes into the office every day and spends all day trying to do their work, it is obnoxious and inefficient to need to reserve a seating spot and move my laptop, keyboard and mouse, headset, etc., back an forth between a locker and the open empty tables we're now forced to squeeze into. Having any personal items in your area results in directors complaining and circulating emails and pictures of you and your belongings. You are essentially shamed for trying to add any amount of individuality to your area, and are viewed as an unimportant work ant whose sole purpose is to quietly come in, do work, and leave without any trace of you ever having been there. There are a slew of similar acts committed by the company and senior management, but all point to the base result that unless you are a senior manager or director, you are viewed as insignificant and they have no problem treating you as such.
Advice to Management
Understand that you're not a better human just because of your job title; humans need to be able to express who they are and be in a comfortable environment in order to be efficient and productive.

pros: The company as a whole is a great organization in terms of scale and span. They offer a great benefits package, including 401K matching and liberal paid time off as well as paternity leave for men. They also offer tuition reimbursement. Working for a fortune 100 company has about the same pros everywhere, regarding the Tampa office there was nothing specifically outstanding.
cons:
The Tampa office is poorly ran and turnover is high. You are a production employee, not valued for your mind, but more so how well you follow directions and how timely you follow them. You are told that successful people are the ones who work weekends and nights and work/life balance isn't something that is valued or even spoken about. Certain claims managers rule with a iron fist and make no excuse for their behavior and almost celebrate their hard-nose approach. You have to know someone in order to move outside of your current role, it's a very political environment. They will stop you from going onto a position another department wants to offer you if it does not fit their staffing model. It took a little over a year under that management to run a 13 year employee away.
Advice to Management
Being a fortune 100 company it is easy to not adapt to the changing landscape of employee mental/emotional well-being, however, in my time there I saw great turnover and repeated feedback given regarding the nastiness of certain members of leadership ignored or not addressed at all. Be harder on your leadership team than individual contributors because it is leadership's responsibility to empower and guide and if you have a bad tree it will always produce bad fruit. Be more agile in your approach to management theory and style. Also, be upfront about things in terms of culture and management style to these poor college kids you are recruiting or you will continue to see talent come and go.
Helpful (4

review_title: It's not really all about the customer
pros: Very organized and efficient company. Everyone seems very nice for the most part-at first. Good about breaks and lunches and leaving on time.
cons:
It's really all about metrics. Don't help customers too much, or it looks bad for your call time. So basically, instead of getting an issue resolved in one call is okay if you can do it in less than 2 minutes. So, sub par service is okay, because your job is to get them off the phone. Lots of passing the buck. Also, when you start the entire process letting them know from the time of interview about a licensing issue in one state (not the state where I was working for liberty), I was told it was ok. Even spoke to legal. And told since license wasn't rejected, it wouldn't be a problem and we could just mark me in the system not to take calls from x state. Then, I got sick. By that point, I was actually providing"good enough" service and meeting all metrics. While I was out on FMLA, all the sudden my licensing issue became a problem.
Advice to Management
Why hire an employee when you know they aren't going to be able to be licensed in one state if you're then going to turn around and use it against them? Oh, and stop picking favorites. Kinda reverse racism as many leaders are of color, and definitely give special treatment to those with pigmented skin.

pros: I have plenty of good things to say about Liberty! Work from home 2 days per week, very competitive salary (Boston) , plentiful role mobility, career advancement opportunities, flex office space, learning opportunities, career growth, free coffee and tea, impressive maternity AND paternity paid leave (new 2019), 100% tuition reimbursement up to 9k per year after 12 months of service, young culture, ERGs (employee resource groups to encourage acceptance and diversity.. ex "Pride at Liberty" the LGBTQ+ group)
cons:
Flex time off- 15 days +3 personal holidays.. 18 days total to start. This wouldn't be bad if there was a separate bank for sick time. 18 days total off is not that competitive to attract top young professional talent. Consider moving that figure to 20+.. 15 day FTO accrual is very standard, but typically an employee would also get sick time. The commuter benefit is only "pretax" so basically no contribution from Liberty Mutual, which is a shame in an expensive city like Boston. The gym discounts for local gyms typically range from 10-30 dollars of per month, laughable considering most gyms in the area are a minimum of 100 month, most reaching upwards of 200 per month.
Advice to Management
Keep up with modernizing the work place/culture. Young professionals value the WFH, ERGs, work/life balance, and the ample career opportunities! Considering starting with 20 days FTO like another close competitors in Massachusetts, and consider more fitness/ commuting contributions.

review_title: There is No Liberty at Liberty
pros: Benefits are good. HSA, 401K, Health and Dental are standard. Good perks and discounts. Co-workers are helpful and friendly.
cons:
Chronically understaffed, lack of departmental and interdepartmental communication, cumbersome procedures, archaic systems, useless practices. In summary this position is a waste of life. 

Interview: The process includes a phone interview and an in person double-teamed interview, both loaded with “name an example of a time…” meandering questions. 

Salary: The range is between $39K and $48K. Of course, they will try to offer you $39K. No one should do this job for less than $50K. Actually, no one should do this job, period. Well, maybe an evil robot. This is an hourly position, however with authorized and unauthorized overtime it will feel like a salaried position.

Training: This is a honeymoon period in which you would have to travel (most likely to Boston) for 2 weeks. Then you will enjoy a slow-paced job shadowing and administrative tasks easy-peasy weeks before the job becomes a brain-eating amoeba. 

The Job: Involves attending useless meetings, getting 10-15 new claims daily, calling all parties and sifting through their lies because an accident is never anyone’s fault. 
Claim 1: “The Earth spun too fast that day and I lost control of the vehicle." 
Claim 2: “When I saw my parked, unoccupied car get hit I got a hernia. I want a million dollars.” Claim 3: “My hamster, Pepe, was in the car and he was injured too.” 
Every other claim can be featured on an episode of CNBC’s American Greed. You deny a word vs word claim per the company's guidelines, but if a claimant barks loud enough, or has some power, management or the insured cave in and accept liability, making you look like an idiot. You could have saved weeks of insults and aggravation by simply accepting liability right away. Threats of bodily harm by claimants are not uncommon. Insureds act as if they own you. You are a secretary, personal doormat, complaint department operator and sometimes a claims adjuster. 
While some of these things are common in most insurance companies. Liberty does it worse. 
The job is extremely stressful. It is impossible to complete all tasks during the shift, but getting overtime is like pulling teeth on a demented shark. Some employees choose to work OT unpaid (which is illegal) and management looks the other way. Business plans, priorities, lower and upper management change drastically every 6 to 8 months in some sort of corporate three-legged musical chairs that leaves everyone disoriented and unstable. Guidelines are as unclear as Chicago parking signs, and are overruled the second the right dog barks too loud. Sales and underwriting live in Jupiter while here on Earth adjusters need to battle through coverage wars with insureds who always believe they purchased coverage for the Sears Tower even though they are paying premium to cover a bus stop. 

An accurate job description should be: "Looking for argumentative person to battle gladiator style with customers". In order to be successful you have to, not just be comfortable with conflict, you have to enjoy it. You have to get satisfaction out of being combative and argumentative like some prosecutors. Even if you enjoy conflict, without support from management this task is like showing up to a world war with a plastic fork. Pointless!

Communications:
You are expected to answer phone calls, mail, emails, and texts from customers, vendors, claimants, brokers and other carriers for your claims and other people’s claims. This sounds reasonable, except for the fact that Liberty is chronically understaffed constantly so the calls, emails, and texts flow like the freezing water that sunk the Titanic. It’s simply overwhelming to try to answer a hundred emails in 4 hours on top of working the 10-15 new claims you’ll get a day plus calls and meaningless huddles. 

Management Support: Standing dominoes on a Bosu ball during an earthquake are more stable than some managers. There’s a manager in particular who likes to call you into his office to see how much yelling your eardrums can take. A death metal band plays at a lower volume than his screams. Half of the office can hear him badgering employees.

Health: Several people have dealt with work-related health issues throughout the years. Empty bottles of alcohol have been found in the bathroom from time to time. Panic attacks and anxiety are contagious like the common cold. Work-Life balance? Ha! There's a generous PTO bank. However, you'll spend your vacation panicking about what awaits when you return. 

FAQ:

“Why didn’t you leave earlier?” Others and I kept waiting for it to get better but that is like being married to the bear in The Revenant and expecting the bear to not attack you.
“It can’t be that bad! Are you exaggerating?” We are not. Ask about the turnover rate. Ask the person you job-shadow how many panic attacks they’ve had in the last six months. Ask them when was the last time they had a full night sleep…sober! Ask who’s not on a mental health medication due to the job. Ask the few lifers left, who have been there since the Y2K, how many managers they’ve had. It's more than the coaches the Chicago Bears have had. 

To add insult to life-threatening injury, with the right creamer, sewage water from Flint, MI tastes better than their free coffee.
Advice to Management
Honestly, I would only recommend this job to a committed middle manager who is willing to accept the challenge of changing once and for all the toxic culture of this commercial insurance auto claims department; Someone who is willing to embrace employees’ concerns in order to implement unwavering and clear guidelines that apply to every claimant, customer, and employee equally; Someone who prides themselves on stellar communication skills and will not change their mind every other day.

Good Luck Everyone!

pros: Training is second to none in insurance industry. Pay during training is also very good. They've even increased it by another 10k since I worked there.
cons:
Pay is low. Most commissions for auto/home sales are roughly 10%. That's lower than the average insurance carrier's commission, but Liberty claims to make it up in covered overhead. The issue is Liberty is simultaneously trying to cut the costs of office space for their sales team and making their sales team come into the office every day. They claim the job is "outside sales", but you will spend well over 90% of your time inside due to mandatory outbound call events and repetitive, mandatory 30 minute morning meetings. Some offices do not have a meeting EVERY morning, instead opting for 3 a week, but some have them every single morning. 

The biggest problem Liberty Mutual has is too many managers. There are 9 steps on the ladder from you to the CEO, and each step up is even further removed from knowing what's going on beneath them. Virtually the only managers you will ever meet are your branch and area managers. They wield no power over the price of your product and the rules of how much (or how little) you can market yourself, but they have managers breathing down their necks to increase production. If any issue arises, managers can "look the other way" at their discretion, but this just allows for favorites to be played, and they absolutely are. If you don't believe this to be true, then you're a favorite. At different times during my decade with Liberty, I was on both ends of the spectrum.

Liberty Mutual management cares about 2 things. Making money and cutting costs. Sales agents are on their own when it comes to paying for marketing themselves, but you can't do too public of marketing (like newspaper ads or billboards). As I mentioned before, you'll be required to spend the vast majority of time in the office so management can see that you are working, but Liberty is trying to push for "flex space" offices which have a shared desk per 3 or 4 workers - erasing their argument of why they pay their reps so little. Your paid time off is just based off of your base salary, which after a few years is roughly 16k. So if you take a week off, you better hope your renewals are enough to help you pay your bills, as you will only be paid your low base salary and renewals for the week you didn't make any new sales. And, by the way, the renewals are roughly 1%. You will be worked like a rat on a wheel. You will never be able to take it easy. You will grind for the little they give you until you leave jobs or retire.

They allow for other carriers to be sold, provided Liberty Mutual's initial rate was too high (which is about 80-90% of the time), but the new business commission you make is less than half of what that carrier usually pays. The renewals for the other carriers are also just 1%.

Despite the ridiculously high number of managers, if you'd like to move up you have to wait for them to retire or die, as very few people shift jobs once they hit management. The managers are paid fairly well, have bonuses, and can take normal time off. Salespeople who obtain management positions rarely leave. 

Is it possible to make a lot of money at Liberty Mutual as a sales rep? Yes, but the odds are low that you will make more than 100k until maybe year 3 or 4, and even then, you'll have to work like a dog to keep it, as the renewals are so low taking it easy is going to drop your yearly income substantially.

Oh, and the CEO took a bonus that was higher than the entire company's profit in 2017.
Advice to Management
You could honestly do without 5 of the 9 management levels.
Helpful (17
advice_to_mgmt: You could honestly do without 5 of the 9 management levels.

review_title: Home office is full of egotistical airheads
pros: Benefits are okay, there are some interesting projects (at least in insurance terms) that are available
cons:
Huge disconnect with every claims office and the home office. Representatives and corporate employees do not get treated the same and are often not on the same page. This is a review of the culture in the home office.

DIVERSITY! DIVERSITY! DIVERSITY! The home office is so focused on telling you how diverse and inclusive it is that you almost need to ask, "Why are you shoving this in our face so much? Just let me work."

People in the home office seem to want to always talk about what they did before joining Liberty. And that's fine in an initial introduction, but not when you are constantly working with them (and don't do it if your previous research doesn't apply to the insurance industry at all). This is different for young employees in their 20s, but when you're in your mid-30s and later you probably should let your college research go. No one cares if you did it at Harvard. Especially if the field isn't insurance or financial based.

Everything moves very slow. Insurance is a conservative industry in terms of financials, but Liberty is even more conservative than the likes of Geico or Allstate.

Being a large company also has a lot of bureaucracy built in. Getting anything in a timely manner is a hassle.
Advice to Management
Just lay off some of the rules.
Helpful (8
advice_to_mgmt: Just lay off some of the rules.

pros: Great benefits and compensation. With ability to set your own schedule

Helpfu

pros: Amazing co-workers and the flexible work schedule.
cons:
Liberty Mutual has zero integrity. They laid off an entire department with less than a months notice right before the holidays and bonuses. Our health plan expired at midnight on our termination date, and management refused to provide any letters of recommendations. They refused to answer any questions and many of the staff members are still displaced. The truth was our jobs were outsourced and it is only a matter of time before the paralegal’s jobs are next.
Advice to Management
Most people understand business decisions, but remember it is the worker bees that make it possible for you to shine and for your stockholders and executives to receive their bonuses. There is always a right and respectful way to do things and terminating employees without offering job replacements or services is wrong. When I speak of job replacement I’m not referring to applying for a job, comparable jobs should have been assigned to employees. Yes, they paid for a resume writing class but a lot more could have been done especially for those that were hired 2 months before we received notice of termination. The company knew in advance and should have frozen all job postings.

pros: It's a great company which really does care about all of its internal and external customers. They offer a great salary and wonderful benefits for entry level positions. They are constantly evaluating and attempting to improve their work/life balance. The position offers a lot of meaning since you actually have the power to help people. There are many different shift options available.
cons:
It is a very stressful job for introverts or those who may have sensory processing issues. The metrics are very strict and you need to be able to empathize and rush people along at the same time. It is a constantly changing environment and you need to stay on top of those changes.
Advice to Management
Understand that there are some personalities which do not work well at this kind of job no matter how hard they try. Learn to recognize these people and then advocate for them to be promoted to a different position even though they may not be outperforming their current peers at the time. Weaknesses and strengths often mirror one another so even though this position may showcase a person's weaknesses if you learn how that proves their strengths you may be able to figure out what they would be good at and help them to attain a position they would thrive at and that the company would benefit from.
Practice empathy and direct communication.

review_title: AWFUL Company ! No work life balance and a computer program is to set your fate!
pros: They recently decided to let a lot of people work from home in other states, not Arizona, but I think that will help a lot of us with kids, and pets and issues with vehicles. I also think the pay is decent for some roles- but not all.
cons:
Working at Liberty Mutual in Chandler, AZ you will find NO work-life balance. After getting licensed, they still treat you like a basic unskilled customer service agent as opposed to a licensed insurance agent. They just rolled a program called COGITO out which is artificial intelligence that listens to your calls and tells you when you are not doing well on a call with a policyholder. It was designed to tell you when your energy is low or too high or when you are too silent- totally ignoring the fact that we are human and know when to reply and or may have a bad day or medicine or medical condition preventing us from being SUPER high energy. There is constant change, with no regard to pay scale and or the fact that we all have to deal with stats and upset customers they raise prices on while adhering to their policy changes. There is no gray area, it seems to all be black and white. The turn over rate is high and it has a lot to do with the impossible metrics and forcing Insurance agents who work in customer service to hunt down leads- aggressively. There are several supervisors and managers within the Chandler CRC who are passive aggressive and really nasty! They try and pretend and hide it behind false professionalism, but it's a high-stress environment because most people believe they will be fired any day for doing anything wrong- most of us have been here over 2 years and still feel this way!
Advice to Management
Please get rid of this program Cogito. WOrk with employees on Work-Life Balance. Auto Plus reps should be paid for Renters Policy work. Customer Service/ Insurance Agents should get a percentage of leads that are bound!
Helpful (7
advice_to_mgmt: Please get rid of this program Cogito. WOrk with employees on Work-Life Balance. Auto Plus reps should be paid for Renters Policy work. Customer Service/ Insurance Agents should get a percentage of leads that are bound!

pros: Pay and benefits were VERY good, some groups will allow working remotely (a godsend to be out of the office, which is a very negative environment), good opportunity for learning (but offset by favoritism by management) nice office equipment (high quality adjustable desks, nice workstations).
cons:
Isolating, no sense of comradely, poor management, lots of layoffs due to the opening of the Plano ginormous office, limited career opportunities unless you are in the Dover NH office. 
Having worked for Liberty Mutual for years, I found the place to be one of constantly having to meet the never achievable standards to hang onto my position. I felt beat down and that my performance was never good enough. I stayed there for years because the company breeds Stockholm syndrome and that you will never be able to get a “better” job elsewhere with your skillet. 
The Seattle location has moved much of its operations to Plano and it’s rumored that soon, the company will work out of that location. Often I’d speak to claims employees who were just swamped with work. One adjuster said that it’s not uncommon for them to take vacation time only to work to maintain the workload.
Advice to Management
Treat employees better, stop focusing on acquisitions and invest in employees. It doesn’t take much to acknowledge that an employee is valuable and appreciated. This company could be so much better if employees were shown some respect.
